chapters.title: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Eigenvalues
chapters.description: An overview of Principal Component Analysis (PCA), a technique for transforming high-dimensional feature spaces into lower-dimensional ones by identifying key directions of variance using eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

topics.title: How PCA Works
topics.summary: PCA operates by transforming a dataset into a new set of uncorrelated variables called principal components. This is achieved by first calculating the covariance matrix of the data, then finding its eigenvectors and eigenvalues. The eigenvectors with the highest eigenvalues represent the directions of maximum variance and become the new principal components.
key_points: First, calculate the covariance matrix of the dataset.
Next, calculate the eigenvectors and eigenvalues of the covariance matrix.
The eigenvector with the highest eigenvalue points in the direction of the highest variance, becoming the first principal component.
The top 'k' eigenvectors are selected to form the new 'k' dimensional feature space.
quiz_questions: What does the eigenvector with the highest eigenvalue represent in PCA?
What is the first matrix you need to calculate when performing PCA?
topics.image_hint: diagram showing data points with principal component axes

topics.title: Applications of PCA
topics.summary: PCA is a powerful tool used in machine learning and data analysis for various purposes. Its applications range from visualizing complex, high-dimensional data to resizing images, analyzing financial data, and identifying important factors in healthcare research.
key_points: Used to visualize multidimensional data by reducing it to 2D or 3D.
Helps resize images by capturing their most important features.
Applied in healthcare to explore risk factors for chronic diseases.
Utilized to analyze stock data, forecast trends, and find patterns in high-dimensional datasets.
quiz_questions: Name two practical applications of Principal Component Analysis.
How can PCA be used in the field of image processing?
